__data__.text: In the early 1920s, radio broadcasting started consolidating, with Radio Corporation of America (RCA) acquiring WEAF from American Telephone & Telegraph (AT&T) and transferring Westinghouse's WJZ to RCA. WEAF served as a lab for AT&T's manufacturing outlet, Western Electric, and was successful with sponsored programs. In 1923, RCA tried transmitting audio between cities using low-quality telegraph lines, but it failed due to interference. AT&T sold WEAF and WCAP to RCA in 1925, forming the National Broadcasting Company (NBC) with RCA, General Electric, and Westinghouse as owners. NBC had two networks: the Red Network for commercially sponsored entertainment and the Blue Network for non-sponsored broadcasts. In 1927, NBC expanded to the West Coast with the Orange and Gold Networks. NBC moved to 711 Fifth Avenue in 1933 and developed a shortwave radio network. After General Electric was charged with antitrust violations in 1930, RCA moved to the Rockefeller Center in 1933.

In the early 1930s, NBC developed a shortwave radio network, known as the NBC White Network. Due to antitrust violations, General Electric divested itself of RCA, leading to RCA's move to the Rockefeller Center in 1933, where NBC's production studios and RCA-owned RKO Pictures theaters were housed. The iconic three-note NBC chimes, which were first used in 1931, were mechanized by Rangertone founder Richard H. Ranger for system cues between the Red and Blue network feeds. In 1938, the FCC began investigating the monopolistic effects of network broadcasting, leading to an order for RCA to divest itself of either NBC Red or NBC Blue. In 1942, the Blue Network was sold to the American Broadcasting System, owned by Life Savers magnate Edward J. Noble, for $8 million.

In 1942, the Blue Network was officially named NBC Blue Network, Inc., and NBC Red became NBC Red Network, Inc. After being sold to the American Broadcasting System (ABC) in 1943, it was renamed the American Broadcasting Company (ABC) on June 15, 1945. The sale included the Blue Network name, leases on landlines, New York studios, two-and-a-half radio stations, contracts with actors, and agreements with around 60 affiliates. NBC, on the other hand, became home to many popular performers and programs during radio's golden age, but began losing talent to CBS in the late 1940s due to CBS's policy of allowing radio stars to use their own production companies. In response to the defection of Jack Benny and other NBC performers to CBS, NBC launched The Big Show in 1950, featuring Tallulah Bankhead and other prestigious entertainers, but it only lasted two years due to declining radio audiences. NBC's last major radio programming push was Monitor, which began on June 12, 1955.

After being sold to ABC in 1943, the Blue Network was renamed to the American Broadcasting Company (ABC), while NBC focused on popular performers and programs during radio's golden age. In response to losing talent to CBS, NBC launched The Big Show in 1950, featuring prestigious entertainers, but it only lasted two years due to declining radio audiences and financial losses. NBC's last major radio programming push was Monitor, which began in 1955 and featured a mix of music, news, interviews, and features. Despite initial success, Monitor's popularity waned in the mid-1960s as local stations became reluctant to break from their established formats. NBC made further attempts at radio programming, including the NBC News and Information Service (NIS) and The Source, but both were eventually discontinued. In 1985, GE reacquired RCA and announced its intent to sell off NBC's radio holdings. The NBC Radio Network, The Source, NBC Talknet, and NBC Radio Entertainment were sold to Westwood One in 1987, marking the end of NBC's radio network.

After NBC's radio network was sold to Westwood One in 1987, the stations were sold to various companies, including Emmis Communications, Westinghouse, and Susquehanna Radio Corporation, by 1989. NBC Radio News moved to Mutual's Arlington, Virginia, facility, with engineering operations and the affiliate relations department following suit. In 1992, Mutual and NBC newscasts were jointly produced during overnights and weekends, and both networks aired generic sportscasts through the weekend. Westwood One purchased Unistar Radio Networks in 1994, becoming its largest shareholder and assuming control. Infinity, which later acquired Westwood One, became the parent of CBS/Westinghouse Broadcasting in 1996, with the CBS Radio Network also falling under Westwood One management. The Mutual/NBC newsroom in Arlington closed in 1998, and "NBC"-branded newscasts were restricted to morning drive (ET) on weekdays. Westwood One ended distribution of CNN Radio newscasts and made NBC News Radio a full-time operation in April 2012. NBC Sports Radio was launched that September as a Dial Global/NBC Sports joint venture but ended 24/7 programming in 2018 and was shut down in March 2020. Cumulus Media acquired Dial Global in 2013, and NBC News Radio ended operations in December 2014. Since July 2016, iHeartMedia has produced "NBC News Radio"-branded newscasts via a licensing agreement with NBCUniversal. Television.

In the context of the original text, this summary focuses on the sale and consolidation of NBC's radio network after 1985, when GE reacquired RCA and announced its intent to sell off NBC's radio holdings. The text highlights the various companies that acquired NBC's radio stations, the gradual phasing out of NBC's radio presence, and the eventual licensing agreement with iHeartMedia for "NBC News Radio"-branded newscasts. This summary retains all propositions from the original text and is significantly shorter while remaining conceptually similar.

After DuMont Laboratories introduced home television sets in 1938, NBC began broadcasting professional football and baseball games in the New York City area, leading to the first NBC Television "network" program in January 1940. Despite RCA's promotion, television sales in New York from 1939 to 1942 remained low due to high set costs and lack of regular programming. The experimental period ended in July 1941, allowing full-fledged commercial television broadcasts, with NBC's W2XBS in New York City becoming WNBT and airing the first paid advertisement. Limited commercial programming, including NBC's earliest non-paid television commercials, was seen during the first Major League Baseball game telecast in 1939. Regular weekly television broadcasts started in 1944, with The Voice of Firestone Televues as the first program sent from New York City to affiliated stations in Philadelphia and Albany/Schenectady.

After the experimental period, limited commercial television broadcasts started in 1941, with NBC's W2XBS in New York City becoming WNBT and airing the first paid advertisement. Regular weekly television broadcasts began in 1944, with "The Voice of Firestone Televues" as the first program sent from New York City to affiliated stations in Philadelphia and Albany/Schenectady. Commercial programming continued until the U.S. entered World War II, and telecasts resumed expanding as NBC prepared for full-time service upon the end of the war. "The War As It Happens" became the first news cast regularly seen in multiple cities in April 1944.

WNBT broadcast several hours of news coverage and remotes from around New York City on V-E Day, May 8, 1945. The NBC television network grew from its initial post-war line-up of four stations, and the 1947 World Series brought success to NBC Television with increased sales. Under its president, Sylvester "Pat" Weaver, the network launched several successful shows, including Today and The Tonight Show.

In 1951, NBC commissioned Gian Carlo Menotti to compose the first opera ever written for television, Amahl and the Night Visitors, which was a huge success. NBC began broadcasting in color in 1954, using the RCA-compatible color system, which became the U.S. standard. NBC broadcast a live production in color of Peter Pan, a new Broadway musical adaptation, in 1955.

After CBS abandoned its incompatible color broadcast system, NBC adopted the RCA-compatible color system, which became the U.S. standard. NBC quickly began broadcasting in color, starting with a few shows in 1954 and transitioning more extensively by 1955. The network established a subsidiary, California National Productions, for merchandising, syndication, and opera company operations. In 1956, NBC's Chicago station became the first to air all programming in color. The network's production of The Bell Telephone Hour began in 1959, and Walt Disney's anthology series moved to NBC in color in 1961. By 1963, much of NBC's prime time schedule was in color, and the network began calling itself "The Full Color Network" in 1965, when it broadcast 95% of its prime time schedule in color. Rival networks followed suit in the 1966-67 season. NBC also produced the first feature-length film for television, See How They Run, in 1964, and acquired the broadcast rights to the classic film The Wizard of Oz in 1967.

After NBC adopted the RCA-compatible color system and started broadcasting in color in the mid-1950s, it became known as "The Full Color Network" by 1965, airing 95% of its prime time schedule in color. The network produced the first feature-length film for television, See How They Run, in 1964, and acquired the broadcast rights to The Wizard of Oz in 1967. Despite the film's success, NBC did not broadcast another made-for-TV film for two years.

During the late 1960s, networks like NBC aimed to attract younger viewers and modernize programming to resemble contemporary society, targeting adults aged 18-49. This led to the cancellation of older shows, including The Bell Telephone Hour and Sing Along With Mitch on NBC. Despite initial success with new shows and continued popularity of some veteran programs, NBC entered a slump in the 1970s.

In 1974, NBC, under new president Herbert Schlosser, attempted to draw younger viewers with expensive movies, miniseries, and specials, but this strategy failed and alienated older viewers. The network's prime-time lineup introduced in the fall of 1975 performed poorly, with no shows earning a second season renewal. NBC's lone success that season was the late-night comedy/variety show Saturday Night Live, which debuted in 1976.

In 1978, Fred Silverman joined NBC from top-rated ABC to improve the network's performance. Although he had some success with shows like CHiPs, Diff'rent Strokes, Real People, and the miniseries Shōgun, many other shows under his leadership failed, such as Hello, Larry, Supertrain, Pink Lady and Jeff, season six of Saturday Night Live, and The Waverly Wonders.

During the late 1970s and early 1980s, NBC experienced a decline in ratings and lost several longtime affiliates to ABC and CBS. This was due in part to the failure of many shows produced under the leadership of Fred Silverman, who had joined NBC from ABC. Despite some successes like CHiPs, Diff'rent Strokes, Real People, and the miniseries Shōgun, many of Silverman's shows were unsuccessful and lost in the ratings to programs he had previously greenlit at CBS and ABC. This period also saw the cancellation of older shows and the loss of affiliates in markets such as Atlanta, Bakersfield, Baltimore, and others. Some of these affiliates were wooed away by ABC, which had become the #1 network, while others joined CBS. In some cases, NBC was forced to affiliate with UHF stations, which were less desirable due to their lower viewership. However, some stations have since returned to the network. The decline of NBC during this time was due to a combination of poor programming choices and the loss of affiliates to competitors.

The late 1970s and early 1980s were challenging for NBC due to declining ratings and lost affiliates to competitors like ABC and CBS. This was partly because of the unsuccessful shows produced under Fred Silverman's leadership, who joined NBC from ABC. The network's situation worsened when President Jimmy Carter pulled the U.S. team out of the 1980 Summer Olympics, causing NBC to cancel its planned 150 hours of coverage.

Silverman faced internal and external criticism, including a parody song called "Loud as a Peacock" and a Saturday Night Live sketch titled "A Limo For A Lame-O." After Silverman's resignation, Grant Tinker and Brandon Tartikoff took over as president and entertainment division president, respectively.

Tartikoff focused on nurturing promising shows, such as the critically acclaimed Hill Street Blues, despite its poor ratings. He moved it to Thursdays, where its ratings improved significantly. He employed similar tactics with St. Elsewhere and Cheers. These shows, along with Gimme a Break!, Silver Spoons, Knight Rider, and Remington Steele, attracted desirable demographics and helped NBC through the disastrous 1983-84 season.

In 1982, NBC replaced Tom Snyder's The Tomorrow Show with Late Night with David Letterman, which became a successful late-night talk franchise. The Cosby Show's success in 1984 led to renewed interest in sitcoms, and Family Ties and Cheers saw increased viewership after being Cosby's lead-in.

In terms of affiliations, NBC made a strategic upgrade in Wheeling by partnering with WTOV-TV in Steubenville, Ohio, overtaking former affiliate WTRF-TV in the ratings. Smaller markets like Yuma, Arizona, had to wait for local NBC affiliates, while some markets, such as Baltimore, Columbia, Dayton, Jacksonville, Savannah, and Temple, rejoined the network. However, El Dorado became a full-time Fox affiliate, Green Bay switched to CBS, and Bakersfield went to ABC. In Rapid City, the KOTA calls now reside on a station owned by Gray Television.

In the early 1980s, NBC faced significant challenges, including declining ratings, lost affiliates, and the cancellation of the 1980 Summer Olympics coverage. Fred Silverman's unsuccessful shows, such as The Tomorrow Show, further worsened the situation. However, the appointment of Grant Tinker and Brandon Tartikoff as president and entertainment division president, respectively, led to a turnaround. Tartikoff focused on nurturing promising shows, like Hill Street Blues, despite their poor ratings, and moved them to different time slots for better performance.

In 1982, NBC replaced The Tomorrow Show with Late Night with David Letterman, which became a successful late-night talk franchise. The network also started repairing its old affiliations and conceived a syndication package for its owned-and-operated stations in 1987, consisting of five sitcoms. These shows, along with others like The Cosby Show, Family Ties, and Cheers, helped NBC recover from the disastrous 1983-84 season and regain its position in the ratings.

In the mid-1980s, NBC, which had been struggling with low ratings and cancellations, experienced a resurgence due to the leadership of Grant Tinker and Brandon Tartikoff. Tartikoff focused on nurturing promising shows and moving them to different time slots for better performance. A significant turning point was the launch of Late Night with David Letterman in 1982, which became a successful late-night talk franchise. In 1987, NBC took advantage of the relaxation of the Prime Time Access Rule and Financial Interest and Syndication Rules to create a syndication package for its owned-and-operated stations, consisting of five sitcoms. Although these shows initially struggled against popular syndicated game shows, they helped NBC recover from the disastrous 1983-84 season and regain its position in the ratings. NBC's success continued into the early 1990s with new hits such as The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air, Blossom, and Law & Order. Tartikoff's strategy of nurturing promising shows and moving them to different time slots proved to be a successful one, as evidenced by the success of shows like Seinfeld, Friends, and Frasier, which became some of the network's biggest television shows.

In the 1990s, NBC's success continued with shows like "Friends" and "Frasier," which became massive hits and dominated the ratings. The network's "Must See TV" lineup on Thursdays became particularly popular. However, NBC's fortunes began to decline in the early 2000s when CBS overtook it for first place in the ratings. NBC tried to attract new viewers by airing select dramas in letterbox, but only saw a slight boost. The network lost the rights to the AFC in 1998, which had been a significant source of revenue and viewership. Despite these challenges, shows like "Friends," "Will & Grace," "ER," and "Just Shoot Me!" helped NBC maintain its lead on Thursday nights.

In the early 2000s, NBC's ratings lead ended as CBS overtook it, marking the end of NBC's nearly two-decade dominance on Thursday nights. CBS's success with Survivor hinted at this shift. Despite this, shows like "Friends," "Will & Grace," "ER," and "Just Shoot Me!" helped NBC maintain its lead on Thursday nights. NBC started airing select dramas in letterbox to attract new viewers, but only saw a slight boost. The network lost the rights to the AFC, Major League Baseball, and the NBA, which had been significant sources of revenue and viewership. NBC acquired Spanish-language network Telemundo and merged with Vivendi Universal Entertainment, forming NBC Universal. In 2004, NBC experienced a decline in ratings due to the loss of popular shows and the rise of competition from cable television, home video, video games, and the Internet. During the 2006-07 season, NBC had mixed results with both successful and unsuccessful shows, but managed to win the Emmy Award for Outstanding Comedy Series for four consecutive years with "The Office" and "30 Rock."

In the 2006-07 season, NBC's ratings fell to fourth place due to increased competition from cable TV, home video, video games, and the Internet. Despite some successful shows like "Deal or No Deal" and "Heroes," and the return of NFL Sunday Night Football, NBC struggled and remained in fourth place. The network did find success with its summer schedule, particularly with "America's Got Talent." However, NBC failed to produce new primetime hits in the 2008-09 season, and both "Heroes" and "Deal or No Deal" saw significant declines in viewership. In 2009, Comcast announced it would purchase a controlling stake in NBC Universal from General Electric. NBC's broadcast of the 2010 Winter Olympics saw a ratings increase, but the network lost $250 million in advertising revenue. At the end of the 2009-10 season, only a few shows were renewed for second seasons, while many others were canceled. NBC faced further turmoil when it gave Jay Leno a new prime time talk show, which eventually led to Conan O'Brien's departure from "The Tonight Show."

In the 2009-10 season, NBC's ratings struggles continued, resulting in only a few shows being renewed for second seasons. The network's decision to air a daily prime time talk show with Jay Leno received criticism and was ultimately moved to a later time slot. NBC's reputation for airing quality dramas was a concern among industry executives. The network's ratings were minimally affected by the removal of Leno's show. Comcast announced its acquisition of NBC Universal, and Jeff Zucker stepped down as CEO. Steve Burke and Robert Greenblatt took over as CEO of NBCUniversal and chairman of NBC Entertainment, respectively. In 2011, NBC found a hit with "The Voice," but still struggled with new fall programs. The network transitioned to an all-HD schedule, excluding the Qubo consortium's Saturday morning time slot. The broadcast of Super Bowl XLVI and successful Monday night midseason lineup helped NBC lift itself to third place in the 18-49 demographic. However, the network remained in fourth place in total viewership, with only four shows surviving for a second season, and three of them being cancelled the following year. NBC expanded its sitcom roster in the fall of 2012.

In the 2011-12 season, NBC's broadcast of the Super Bowl and successful shows like "The Voice" and "Smash" helped the network move up to third place in the 18-49 demographic. However, it remained in fourth place in total viewership, with only four shows surviving for a second season, and three of them were cancelled the following year. In the fall of 2012, NBC expanded its sitcom roster, leading to a first-place finish in the 18-49 demographic that season. However, midseason ratings suffered due to the delayed release of "The Voice" and "Revolution." The network finished the 2012-13 season in third place, with only three new dramas surviving for a second season. NBC Sports migrated its operations to Connecticut in 2013, and the network became the No. 1 network in the 18-49 demographic that season for the first time since 2003-04. The 2014-15 season was successful for NBC, with the network finishing #1 in the 18-49 demographic and in second place overall. The 2015-16 season was also successful for NBC, with the successful launch of new dramas and comedies. The 2016-17 season brought more success for NBC with the premiere of "This Is Us" and the continued success of "The Blacklist" and the Chicago franchise.

NBC's comedy offerings experienced success in the 2015-16 season with the debut of "Superstore" and the critically acclaimed "This Is Us" in the 2016-17 season, which was renewed for two more seasons. "The Blacklist" continued to perform moderately, but its spinoff, "The Blacklist: Redemption," did not. NBC expanded the "Chicago" franchise with a third spinoff, "Chicago Justice." In the 2016-17 season, the network also introduced "The Good Place" and "The Wall," which brought in modest ratings. The 2017-18 season saw the return of "Will & Grace" and the premiere of successful shows like "Ellen's Game of Games," "Manifest," "Songland," and "New Amsterdam," although "The Village" and "The Enemy Within" were canceled after one season. The network's success in the 2010s was impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic in the 2019-20 season, causing production disruptions and a drop in ratings. However, NBC reclaimed its position as the top-rated network in 2022.
